etymology.type: unclear; ideogrammic compound (Shuowen) or pictogram (Zhang et al.)
etymology.description: Shuowen: semantic 甶 (“head of a ghost”) + 禸 (“to trample”) → a kind of monkey; later view: differentiated from 禹, pictogram of an insect with a decorative mark (cf. 萬).
etymology.interpretation: Early analyses differ: one reading treats it as a compound of ‘ghost-head’ and ‘trampling’, evoking an animal like a monkey. Another line sees a pictograph of a marked creature, with bronze forms resembling masks or the shape of 禹. Its later senses ‘region; corner’ likely arose via semantic shift or phonetic borrowing.

examples.chinese: 我们去了番禺区参观博物馆(我們去了番禺區參觀博物館)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒmen qùle Fānyú Qū cānguān bówùguǎn.
examples.english: We went to Panyu District to visit the museum.

examples.chinese: 文献里“禺”通“隅”，指角落或边隅(文獻裡「禺」通「隅」，指角落或邊隅)。
examples.pinyin: Wénxiàn lǐ “yú” tōng “yú”, zhǐ jiǎoluò huò biānyú.
examples.english: In texts, ‘禺’ is interchangeable with ‘隅’, meaning a corner or edge.

examples.chinese: 传说中的海神禺强掌管海域与风波(傳說中的海神禺強掌管海域與風波)。
examples.pinyin: Chuánshuō zhōng de Hǎishén Yúqiáng zhǎngguǎn hǎiyù yǔ fēngbō.
examples.english: In legend, the sea god Yuqiang presides over the seas and their waves.
